bioghist.p: William Law of Elvingston was the son of John Law, Minister of Campsie and Antermony, near Glasgow, and also Minister in Edinburgh. Law (according to City records) was appointed Regent (or Professor) of Philosophy in 1690. By 1708, he was the Senior Regent and occupant of the Chair of Moral Philosophy. William Law died in 1729.

scopecontent.p: The material consists of: dictates on Ethics, 1696; dictates Physica taken down 1701; Annotationes in ontologgiam Gerrardi de Vries and Annotationes in pneumatologiam Gerrardi de Vries, 1703-1704; and, Annotationes in physicam generalem D. Joannis Clerici, 1705.

relatedmaterial.p: The local Indexes show other references to Law related material in the Laing Collection (check the Indexes for more details): dictates on ethics, 1696, at La.III.152; and, a power of attorney, 1719, at La.III.232. The local Indexes also show reference to notes by Rev. W. Robertson of receipt of stipend from William Law of Elvingston, 1752-1754, 1756-1758 at Dk.6.19/2, but since William Law of Elvingston (Professor of Moral Philosophy) died in 1729, the latter Law may be a son.
